description.narrative: There are many risks and challenges associated with multinational corporations operating in fragile and conflict-affected areas, including human rights abuses; the lack of corporate accountability in such situations; and the risk of sparking or intensifying conflict. Firstly, the risk that corporations become involved in gross human rights abuses is especially prevalent in conflict-affected areas, as the most serious forms of business-related human rights abuses tend to take place in such areas. Secondly, ensuring access to remedy for victims is most challenging when human rights abuses are taking place in such areas due to the 'accountability gap', both in home states as well as host states of multinational companies. Thirdly, in fragile and conflict-affected areas these same companies may also spark, drive or intensify conflict. Their business activities may benefit and support specific parties to the conflict, for example when sourcing from rebel held territory or supplying them with resources. Also, their presence on the ground may spark conflict when community grievances are not adequately addressed. SOMO and its partners are researching the impacts of MNCs on human rights in conflict-affected areas and analyses how MNCs and conflicts influence each other. SOMO's program on multinationals in conflict-affected areas is partly funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs under its strategic partnership with Oxfam Novib and SOMO, and falls under the Theory of Change Conflict and Fragility. The ultimate aim of our program is to prevent MNCs from contributing to conflict and human rights abuses in conflict-affected areas by increasing corporate accountability, improving government policies, and empowering civil society to do research and hold companies accountable. In the past four years (2012-2015), with funding from Ministry of Foreign Affairs Reconstruction Fund, SOMO worked on company cases in five conflict-affected areas: Democratic Republic of Congo, Liberia, Sierra Leone, South Sudan and Colombia. While these cases are all focused on extractives and the agro-industry, the various contexts were very different in terms of conflict, businesses, governance, and the organization of civil society. In addition, SOMO worked on a number of general research papers on the role of MNCs in conflict-affected areas. In the next five years (2016-2020), the SOMO program on multinationals in conflict-affected areas will have less of a country focus but take on a more flexible approach, doing research in different countries to better respond to current developments. This will increase our understanding of why and how MNCs operate in conflict-affected areas, what role they play in the conflict, and how this affects communities, workers, and the environment. In the first half of 2016, we will strengthen our knowledge by analyzing and structuring the lessons learned of the SOMO program in the first four years and using these lessons in the current phase of the SOMO program. We will also start a new major research project that will cover various relevant MCAA themes. In addition, we will continue the work with partners in various conflict-affected areas, including South Sudan (as well as Colombia, which is not part of the Oxfam-SOMO partnership as it has separate funding through the Dutch Embassy). The Strategic Partnership will be the umbrella under which most of SOMO's work on private sector and conflict will take place, and the results of our research will be shared with Oxfam Novib and its partners in the countries that we will work in or on. The synergy between SOMO and Oxfam Novib will be realized by making use of Oxfam’s lobby and advocacy capacities, in order to call for change in the policies and practices of multinationals in conflict-affected areas, as well as home and host state governments. By 2020, the long term outcome is that policies and practices of both MNCs operating in conflict-affected areas and the states from which they operate (home states) have been influenced through research, dialogue, lobby and other follow up strategies. The aim is to diminish the amount of human rights violations by MNCs in conflict-affected areas, and to make sure that MNCs fulfill the binding and non-binding frameworks for corporate responsibility in conflict-affected contexts. While SOMO and Oxfam Novib would not be able realize this outcome on their own, it is expected that in the frame of the Strategic Partnership, and with the support of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Dutch Embassies in the countries that we work in, there is much more clout to realize the outcome foreseen.

comment.narrative:
[Tax Treaty Research:] In 2017 a Joint research throughout 2017 by a leading Indonesian local partner and SOMO increased the capacities and knowledge of both organisations of research on treaty shopping, specifically on court cases concerning the Indonesia-Netherlands DTA in which corporations successfully claim treaty benefits on the basis of clear conduit structures. The preliminary research results were shared with various stakeholders during a meeting in Indonesia Q3 2017, among which representative from the Directorate-General Taxation in Indonesia. The publication is planned for mid-2018, whilst the outcome of capacity building of both the local partner and SOMO has already been achieved through technical analyses commissioned by the local partner, a literature study by SOMO and its local partner, writing and expert reviews. The local partner in Indonesia coordinates the Asian Tax Justice Alliance, has not conducted research international tax issues before, and developed a methodology for analysing tax court cases which it shared with the a representative from the Directorate-General Taxation in Indonesia and the Indonesian Tax Justice Network
[Tax research training and networking ] In 2017 researchers and policy officers from more than 20 organisations in South East Asia gained corporate tax research skills in a corporate research training organised by SOMO, Oxfam Novib and local partner organisation in July 2017 in Indonesia. The impact of the training was twofold: it strengthened 1) the participants’ capacities and knowledge on tax avoidance by corporations and specifically conducting their own research by analysing corporate accounts in the interactive training workshops and 2) the regional cooperation and networks. During the 3 day training, there was time and space for strategic meetings in which organisations from different countries exchanged experience and knowledge from their own national context and identified possibilities for future cooperation. For example, three organisations from a south eastern country sat together with the local partner to discuss experiences in hosting national tax Justice networks and identifying possibilities for future cooperation. These impacts are further confirmed by the responses to an online survey filled out by 10 participants. Eg: The training was found useful or very useful by all respondents.
[Demystifying how the financial sector is harmful for people] SOMO’s 2017 publication “The underbelly of the financial world” (2017) and a SOMO senior researcher contributed to the discussions of the newly built coalition of NGOs during during the conference “Change Finance”. The conference was attended by 150 CSOs of which 1 was from the South. During 2 plenaries and 1 workshop (attended by 30 people) the issue of the financial sector having a negative impact in the South, people and the environment, and the importance of regulation for sustainable finance were highlighted and discussed with the contribution of SOMO’s lead researcher. These discussions contributed to the understanding of the importance of international and EU regulatory measures to prevent a harmful financial sector and will be followed up in 2018 by a new network of around 70 EU organisations. This contrast with traditions NGO strategies that focused only on putting pressure on the banks rather than the regulators.
By the end of 2017, 3 key organisations from the south and local partners of SOMO, as well as members of the European coalition on regulating EU financiers advocated in writing and political dialogues for EU and international regulatory measures to improve financing practices by banks and pension funds in order to have less negative social impact of these practices at community level in Indonesia and other developing countries. The case study by a local partner and SOMO increased the knowledge how particular practices of the financial industry, including by pension funds, need to be regulated to avoid negative consequences elsewhere in the world.

comment.narrative:
[Raised awareness and knowledge on tax rulings] In 2017, SOMO’s initial FoI request (lodged in July 2015 for research commissioned by Oxfam) on private parties influencing a leading Ministry and tax policies released vital information that led to subsequent requests by others, uncovering information regarding the most common tax rulings in a Northern European country – information that has been secret until now. Tax rulings play a vital role in many aggressive corporate tax planning structures and, as such, have a global impact. These pieces of information led to extensive media coverage (around 5.000 people reached) and 1 debate in Parliament in which the Deputy Minister was forced to release more information. SOMO has subsequently translated the newly found information into English to share it with foreign organisations and members of the European Parliament and provided input – together with TJNL partners – for the parliamentary debate(s) that followed. SOMO contributed by writing one chapter on ‘Tax Games – the Race to the Bottom: Europe’s role in supporting an unjust global tax system’, which includes an in-depth analysis of 17 EU countries and one Scandinavian country revealing that half the countries have an alarming number of harmful tax practices, including 12 governments that cut the corporate tax rate or are planning to do so in the near future. The report is widely used by CSOs in Member States to advocate government to end the race to the bottom and the scoring puts pressure on government to reform harmful tax regimes.
[Demystifying how the financial sector is harmful for people] In 2017 SOMO in cooperation with its Indonesian partner organisation developed a new methodology to raise awareness about the ‘human face of finance’, i.e. the negative social impact of the complex functioning of finance and why (international, EU and national) financial regulation is one of the solutions to such harmful finance by banks and other financial actors. The local partner and SOMO published a particular case of malpractice in Indonesia by a major palm oil company, which explained why and how finance should be change to become more sustainable. The launching of the publication was done in the Fall of 2017 surrounding a conference of the Round Table of Sustainable Palm Oil in Indonesia and also distributed among the members of a Northern European platform on finance and sustainable palm oil. One member of that platform committed to use the methodology as input to its campaign towards the Northern European banks.

comment.narrative: In 2017, SOMO supported LLMIC partners to speak at Eurodad conference 2017 Together with local partners and Oxfam Novib, SOMO co-hosted Eurodad’s International Conference 2017, entitled ‘Alternative policies for a sustainable world. Better ways of financing global development and strengthening global economic regulation and governance’. SOMO actively helped to organise the first days’ panel discussion on the historical role of the Netherlands in global finance and developments, in the international financial and trading systems and in improving development finance. SOMO staff and partner CSOs from India and Indonesia spoke at the panel and various workshops, including on the global tax race to the bottom and how to end it. The need for human rights impact assessments of projects financed with Dutch development aid was discussed at the Eurodad conference with the director of the IOB, the evaluation department of a Ministry of Foreign Affairs, who was one of the main public speakers and confirmed the commitment to human rights protection in development-funded projects.

comment.narrative: [Political commitment to tax reform] By advocating tax reform and participating in Tax Justice Netherlands (TJNL) and Eurodad / Tax Justice Europe, SOMO raised awareness and informed political discussions, particularly in the run up to the March parliamentary elections in 2017. Through contribution together with Oxfam to an in-depth international media article and organising an election debate, Amsterdam on fair taxation, with the outcome of increased party programme commitment to tax reform and anti-avoidance measures. For the first time, all major parties in the Dutch elections mentioned tax avoidance in their electoral programs, even a pro-business political party acknowledged that tax avoidance and evasion exist and that abuses should be tackled.
